summary: This is an FBI Public Affairs News Briefing from January 27, 2021, covering a wide range of national security, criminal, and political news. The primary focus is on the expanding investigation into the January 6 Capitol siege, with updates on arrests, charges, and security failures. It also includes sections on counter-terrorism, counter-intelligence, criminal investigations, financial crime, cyber threats, and international relations, including a brief mention of Ghislaine Maxwell seeking dismissal of her case.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Mentioned in the 'International Relations' section as seeking dismissal of the case accusing her of recruiting teenage girls for Jeffrey Epstein to sexually abuse.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Referenced in the context of the case against Ghislaine Maxwell, who is accused of recruiting girls for him.

persons.name: Michael Sherwin
persons.role: US Attorney for the District of Columbia
persons.context: Quoted discussing the expansion of the Capitol siege investigation and potential sedition charges.

persons.name: Steven D'Antuono
persons.context: Commented on the Capitol investigation and the search for leads on potential future violence.

persons.name: Yogananda Pittman
persons.context: Apologized for security failures on January 6 and testified that intelligence about potential violence was known beforehand.

persons.name: William J. Walker
persons.role: Major General, DC National Guard Commander
persons.context: Stated the Pentagon restricted his authority to deploy troops quickly during the Capitol siege.

persons.name: Ryan McCarthy
persons.context: Testified that the National Guard response did not affect the violence at the Capitol and that there was no prior indication of the threat level.

persons.name: Jen Psaki
persons.context: Spoke about the Biden administration's overhaul of the approach to domestic extremism and other policy matters.

persons.name: Eric Swalwell
persons.context: Stated he learned nothing new about suspected Chinese spy Christine Fang and that the FBI said he did nothing wrong.

persons.name: Gang Chen
persons.context: Mentioned as arrested, with suspicions about his loyalty, in an opinion piece about scrutiny of Chinese-born researchers.

persons.name: Joe Biden
persons.context: Mentioned frequently in the context of administration policies, executive orders, vaccine distribution, and foreign policy calls.

persons.name: Donald Trump
persons.role: Former President of the United States
persons.context: Referenced in relation to the Capitol siege, impeachment trial, pardons, and policy contrasts with the Biden administration.

persons.name: Merrick Garland
persons.context: Mentioned as having named Anthony Coley to lead public affairs at the DOJ.

persons.name: Monty Wilkinson
persons.context: Noted for overturning the Trump-era 'Zero Tolerance' immigration policy.

connections.description: Maxwell is accused of recruiting teenage girls for Epstein to sexually abuse.
Psaki serves as the White House Press Secretary for the Biden administration.
Both provided testimony regarding the security and response failures during the January 6 Capitol siege.
Swalwell was allegedly targeted by suspected Chinese spy Christine Fang.
Both are law enforcement officials involved in the Capitol siege investigation and held a related news briefing.

events.title: Capitol Siege
events.description: A pro-Trump mob stormed the U.S. Capitol, disrupting the certification of the 2020 presidential election results.

events.title: FBI News Briefing Release
events.description: The FBI Public Affairs News Briefing was distributed, summarizing major news including the Capitol investigation, domestic extremism, and other criminal and international matters.

events.title: Senate Vote on Impeachment Trial Constitutionality
events.description: All but five Republican senators voted to declare the impeachment trial of former President Donald Trump unconstitutional.

events.title: Ghislaine Maxwell Seeks Dismissal
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell's attorneys filed a request to dismiss the case against her, citing a Florida nonprosecution agreement with Epstein and grand jury composition issues.

events.title: Biden-Putin Phone Call
events.description: President Biden and Russian President Vladimir Putin discussed extending the New START nuclear arms treaty and other issues including cyber hacking and Ukraine.

keyFacts: The FBI briefing details the massive and expanding investigation into the January 6 Capitol siege, with over 400 suspects identified and about 150 charged as of late January 2021.
Ghislaine Maxwell sought dismissal of her case, arguing a Florida nonprosecution agreement with Jeffrey Epstein shielded her and that the grand jury indictment was flawed.
Acting Capitol Police Chief Yogananda Pittman apologized for security failures on January 6, admitting leaders knew days in advance about threats from armed militia groups.
The Biden administration announced an overhaul of the government's approach to domestic extremism, including policy reviews and efforts to address radicalization.
The document is a broad news digest, with the Epstein/Maxwell case mentioned only briefly in one bullet point under 'International Relations'.
